title: Natural Numbers and Integers
content:
Module 1, Lesson 2: Natural Numbers and Integers

The Hook

The natural numbers (ℕ = {1, 2, 3, ...}) are the counting numbers that humans have used since prehistoric times. Extending them with zero gives the whole numbers, and adding negatives gives the integers (ℤ = {..., -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, ...}). Understanding these foundational sets is essential before tackling fractions, real numbers, and beyond.

The Concept

1. Properties of Integers

Integers obey the commutative law (a + b = b + a), associative law ((a + b) + c = a + (b + c)), and distributive law (a(b + c) = ab + ac). These algebraic identities hold for all real numbers and underpin every calculation you will ever perform.

2. Absolute Value

The absolute value |x| gives the distance of x from zero on the number line. |–7| = 7, |5| = 5. It satisfies the triangle inequality: |a + b| ≤ |a| + |b|.

3. Divisibility and Factors

An integer a divides b (written a | b) if there exists an integer k such that b = ak. The greatest common divisor (GCD) of two integers is the largest integer dividing both. The Euclidean algorithm computes GCD efficiently.

4. Odd and Even Numbers

An even integer satisfies n = 2k for some integer k. An odd integer satisfies n = 2k + 1. The sum of two even numbers is even; the sum of two odd numbers is even; the sum of an odd and an even is odd.

The Illustration

You have reviewed the structure of natural numbers and integers, key properties including divisibility and absolute value, and important parity rules. These foundations will be used throughout every module of this course.
